greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Largest difference between consecutive divisors of n (ordered by size).
comment: Is a(n) the least m > 0 such that n - m divides n! + m? - _Clark Kimberling_, Jul 28 2012
Is a(n) the least m > 0 such that L(n-m) divides L(n+m), where L = A000032 (Lucas numbers)? - _Clark Kimberling_, Jul 30 2012
Records give A006093. - _Omar E. Pol_, Oct 26 2013
link: Reinhard Zumkeller, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
A. Balog, P. Erdős and G. Tenenbaum, On Arithmetic Functions Involving Consecutive Divisors, In: Analytical Number Theory, pp. 77-90, Birkhauser, Basel, 1990.
formula: a(n) = n - A032742(n). - _Omar E. Pol_, Aug 31 2011
example: For n = 35, divisors are {1, 5, 7, 35}; differences are {4, 2, 28}; a(35) = largest difference = 28 = 35 - 35/5.
program: a060681 n = div n p * (p - 1) where p = a020639 n
(PARI) a(n) = if (n==1, 0, n - n/factor(n)[1,1]); \\ _Michel Marcus_, Oct 24 2015
(PARI) first(n) = n = max(n, 1); my(res = vector(n)); res[1] = 0; forprime(p = 2, n, for(i = 1, n \ p, if(res[p * i] == 0, res[p * i] = i*(p-1)))); res \\ _David A. Corneth_, Jan 08 2019
results.author: _Labos Elemer_, Apr 19 2001
ext: a(1)=0 added by _N. J. A. Sloane_, Oct 01 2015 at the suggestion of _Antti Karttunen_
